results.title: Minerals: the materials of earth
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Minerals are the raw materials of rocks. Although there are over 2,000 minerals, only about 200 of them are common. Quartz, diamonds, graphite, are just some of the basic minerals found in the earth’s crust. It is the way in which the atoms are arranged that determine the composition and structure of minerals, as well as their physical properties. It is the correlation between these elements which geologists analyse.

results.title: Earth's interior
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Seismic waves, earthquakes and close study of rocks can give insight into the structure of the Earth. This episode looks at the field of geophysics in order to determine what the three composite parts which make up the Earth’s structure, i.e. the crust, mantle and core, are like. Measuring the magnetism in the Earth and its magnetic fields, looking at heat flow and measuring the Earth’s gravity are discussed. Geophysical research links the study of gravity, magnetism and seismology in order to fully comprehend the complexity of our planet.

results.title: Earth revealed
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description: This 26 part series overviews the fields of geology and the earth sciences. Discusses earthquakes, volcanoes, continental drift, the formation of the sea and the Earth’s resources in short but informative episodes.

results.title: Living with earth: preserving the legacy
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The Industrial Revolution changed the way humans exploited the geological richness of the earth and its resources. With problems of global warming and resource depletion, geologists will play a vital role in assisting scientists in harnessing new energy supplies such as geo-thermal energy. The final message of the series is to not only value the earth for its geological history and structure but to safegaurd it for the future.

results.title: Waves, beaches & coasts
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 24 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Looks at the motion of water particles in a passing wave and how waves are generated by wind. The power of waves shape coastal areas such as bays and headlands. Problems with dredging and the building of sea walls are discussed as well as the creation and effect of devastating seismic waves which result from earthquakes under the sea and on the land.

results.title: Glaciers
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Presents the properties of glaciers and assesses their importance in sculpting Earth’s surface. The study of glacial movement is important in determining the impact of the Greenhouse Effect. By studying the cyclic nature of Ice Ages, geologists can assist scientists in predicting rising sea levels. There are two types of glaciers; valley glaciers which move from mountains down to valleys and continental glaciers which are single giant ice sheets which accumulate in doems on the surface of the planet.

results.title: Wind, dust & deserts
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 22 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Geologists classify deserts as areas with infrequent precipitation so a diversity of formations from Antartica to the Sahara exist as desert landscapes. Movement of the earth and the sun and the roles of wind and rain shadow in the increasing desertification of the planet is examined. Movement of features such as sand dunes has seen an increase in the vastness of deserts and their movement across the surface of the planet.

results.title: Ground water
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 21 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Groundwater is the accumulation of water which seeps through cracks, fissures and faults into the earth and collects in a large quantity beneath the surface. Many continents have large water tables which are accessed through wells and bores. Groundwater seeping through limestone helps form stalectites and stalecmites in caves. Groundwater contamination presents serious health risks therefore geologists who study the movement of water play an important role in assessing potential risks.

results.title: Running water: landform evolution
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 20 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Recognizes the roles human activity can play in itensifying or reducing flood danger. Looks at how rivers cut into landscapes to produce wonders like the Grand Canyon and the formation of deltas and lakes where water and sediment is collected. This episode also looks at how geologists and engineers are tackling the problem of accumulation of silt and sediment in the Mississippi River where three rivers in the delta region are converging.

results.title: Running water: erosion & deposition
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Earth revealed”.
What do rivers do? The power or velocity of river flow is responsible for some of the most unique sculpting of landforms on the planet. Running water transports sediments and deposits it at river mouths and deltas as well as abrasively smoothing and wearing away bedrock on its course. Geologists study the ways rivers flow and meander in order to solve problems of flooding and silting as well as assiting engineers in the construction of dams and dykes in order to improve flow of water.
